conclusion: The fibre core is homogeneous glass with refractive index n surrounded by air with refractive index 1.
The fibre's circular cross-section has diameter D, and when bent, its centre-line becomes an arc of a circle with radius r.
When the fibre is bent, meridional rays are no longer parallel to the local outer surface, reducing the axial angle by δ.
The reduction in angle δ is approximately D/(2r), which is the angle subtended by the core radius at the bend centre.
Before bending, the largest axial angle for total internal reflection is the critical angle θc = arcsin(1/n).
After bending, the incidence angle is reduced by δ, and must still be at least θc to avoid radiating out.
The limiting case is θc - δ = θc(crit) leading to δ = 0.
Any non-zero reduction must leave the incidence angle at least θc(crit), hence δ ≤ θc.
The inequality becomes D/(2r) ≤ arcsin(1/n), and for modest bends, arcsin(1/n) can be approximated as 1/n.
Solving for r gives r_min = nD/2, the smallest radius to ensure total internal reflection.
The turning radius of the fibre’s centre-line must be at least nD/2.
